title: Unit 1: At the Café
description: Learn to order drinks and make simple conversation at a French café.

activities.title: At the Counter
activities.instruction: Listen to the dialogue and follow along.

lines.speaker: Serveur
lines.notes: "Désirez" is more formal than "voulez" — common in service contexts.

lines.speaker: Client
lines.text: Bonjour. Je voudrais un café, s'il vous plaît.
lines.translation: Hello. I would like a coffee, please.

lines.speaker: Serveur
lines.text: Un express ou un café crème ?
lines.translation: An espresso or a coffee with cream?
lines.notes: "Express" is the standard French term for espresso.

lines.speaker: Client
lines.text: Un café crème, s'il vous plaît. Et un croissant.
lines.translation: A coffee with cream, please. And a croissant.

lines.speaker: Serveur
lines.text: Très bien. Vous désirez autre chose ?
lines.translation: Very good. Would you like anything else?

activities.title: Polite Requests with "Je voudrais"
activities.content:
## The Conditional for Polite Requests

**Je voudrais** (I would like) is the conditional form of *vouloir* (to want). It's the standard polite way to make requests in French.

### Formation

| Subject | Conditional |
|---------|------------|
| je | voudrais |
| tu | voudrais |
| il/elle | voudrait |
| nous | voudrions |
| vous | voudriez |
| ils/elles | voudraient |

### Examples

- **Je voudrais un café.** — I would like a coffee.
- **Je voudrais l'addition.** — I would like the check.
- **Vous voudriez autre chose ?** — Would you like anything else?

### Note

Using *je veux* (I want) instead of *je voudrais* sounds blunt and impolite in most situations — similar to saying "I want" vs. "I would like" in English.

activities.title: Conversation: Your Turn at the Café
activities.scenario: You are at a Parisian café. The waiter approaches your table. Order a drink and a pastry. Use polite language (je voudrais, s'il vous plaît).
activities.initialPrompt: Bonjour ! Bienvenue au Café de Flore. Qu'est-ce que je peux vous servir aujourd'hui ?

activities.title: Getting the Check
activities.instruction: Listen to the dialogue between the customer and the waiter.

lines.speaker: Serveur
lines.text: Bien sûr. Alors, un café crème et un croissant... Ça fait quatre euros cinquante.
lines.translation: Of course. So, a coffee with cream and a croissant... That comes to four euros fifty.
lines.notes: "Ça fait" literally means "that makes" — used for totals.

lines.speaker: Client
lines.translation: Here you go. Keep the change.
lines.notes: Tipping is not required in France (service is included), but rounding up or leaving small change is appreciated.

vocab.definition: here you go, there it is

lines.speaker: Serveur
lines.translation: Thank you very much. Have a nice day!
